elements.content: A novel three-dimensional coordination network 1 in a new 4,5,6-connected topology (4,5,6T115) built from linear CuII 4Cl3(H2O)2 clusters and tetrahedral tetrakis­(3-pyridyl)­vinylsilane ligands is reported. Utilizing a similar tetrahedral ligand, tetrakis­(3-pyridyl)­ethylsilane, a different framework 2 having CuII 2Cl­(H2O)2 clusters is obtained in tcs topology. The activated sample of 1 shows an excellent and reversible uptake of I2 in solid as well as in solution phases owing to the presence of uncoordinated chloride ions and electron rich vinylic groups in it. The I2 uptake studies on the anion-exchanged samples, of bromide, iodide, and nitrate ions, show a progressive decrease in the adsorption capacity with the sample containing uncoordinated Cl– ion showing a maximum uptake of 48.5% and the one with the NO3 – ions exhibiting the lowest uptake of 24.0%. These observations suggest that the halide counterions interact better with I2 in comparison with nitrate ions and the better I2 uptake in the presence of Cl– ions over the other two halides is due to its smaller size that offers a larger surface area for adsorption. Also, both these compounds were shown to be useful catalysts for the solvent-free syntheses of bis­(indolyl)­methanes via Friedel–Crafts alkylation reaction.
elements.clean_text: A novel three-dimensional coordination network 1 in a new 4,5,6-connected topology (4,5,6T115) built from linear CuII 4Cl3(H2O)2 clusters and tetrahedral tetrakis(3-pyridyl)vinylsilane ligands is reported. Utilizing a similar tetrahedral ligand, tetrakis(3-pyridyl)ethylsilane, a different framework 2 having CuII 2Cl(H2O)2 clusters is obtained in tcs topology. The activated sample of 1 shows an excellent and reversible uptake of I2 in solid as well as in solution phases owing to the presence of uncoordinated chloride ions and electron rich vinylic groups in it. The I2 uptake studies on the anion-exchanged samples, of bromide, iodide, and nitrate ions, show a progressive decrease in the adsorption capacity with the sample containing uncoordinated Cl- ion showing a maximum uptake of 48.5% and the one with the NO3 - ions exhibiting the lowest uptake of 24.0%. These observations suggest that the halide counterions interact better with I2 in comparison with nitrate ions and the better I2 uptake in the presence of Cl- ions over the other two halides is due to its smaller size that offers a larger surface area for adsorption. Also, both these compounds were shown to be useful catalysts for the solvent-free syntheses of bis(indolyl)methanes via Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction.

elements.content: Starting from rigid and flexible pyridyl functionalized tetrahedral silane ligands two new 3D-coordination networks 1 and 2 were synthesized which respectively comprise the linear CuII 4CI3(H2O)2 and CuII 2CI­(H2O)2 clusters as the secondary building units. The network 1 shows a new 4,5,6-connected topology (4,5,6T115) and exhibits a high reversible uptake of I2. Both these networks act as good catalysts for the synthesis of bis­(indolyl)­methanes via Friedel−Crafts alkylation reactions.
elements.clean_text: Starting from rigid and flexible pyridyl functionalized tetrahedral silane ligands two new 3D-coordination networks 1 and 2 were synthesized which respectively comprise the linear CuII 4CI3(H2O)2 and CuII 2CI(H2O)2 clusters as the secondary building units. The network 1 shows a new 4,5,6-connected topology (4,5,6T115) and exhibits a high reversible uptake of I2. Both these networks act as good catalysts for the synthesis of bis(indolyl)methanes via Friedel-Crafts alkylation reactions.

elements.content: Design and synthesis of three-dimensional coordination networks has received immense attention because of their fascinating structures and perceived potential in the development of materials for adsorbents, catalysis, sensors, molecular sieving, luminescence and drug delivery, etc. These frameworks are typically constructed from the combination of metal ions or clusters of metal ions with multidentate organic ligands. The availability of numerous organic ligands of various geometries and functionalities has allowed the rational design of porous coordination polymers with specific structure and properties. The discovery of structures with new and novel topologies is important from the standpoint of understanding the fundamental correlation among the framework structure, stability, porosity, and interpenetration. Therefore, considerable efforts have been devoted toward the preparation of new ligands and their effects in the assembly of coordination polymers with new and rare topologies.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Design and synthesis of three-dimensional coordination networks has received immense attention because of their fascinating structures and perceived potential in the development of materials for adsorbents, catalysis, sensors, molecular sieving, luminescence and drug delivery, etc. These frameworks are typically constructed from the combination of metal ions or clusters of metal ions with multidentate organic ligands. The availability of numerous organic ligands of various geometries and functionalities has allowed the rational design of porous coordination polymers with specific structure and properties. The discovery of structures with new and novel topologies is important from the standpoint of understanding the fundamental correlation among the framework structure, stability, porosity, and interpenetration. Therefore, considerable efforts have been devoted toward the preparation of new ligands and their effects in the assembly of coordination polymers with new and rare topologies.

elements.content: Use of rigid tetrahedral linkers for constructing metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) is an attractive approach to synthesize novel materials that exhibit intriguing topologies and functional behavior. However, many of such MOFs suffer from the complicated ligand synthesis, limited porosity, and undesired interpenetration. Davies and Zhou et al. have prepared MOFs based on some novel silicon-centered ligands, where the introduction of the silane backbone has largely simplified the process of preparing tetrahedral ligands. Inspired by the utility of polytopic ligand such as tetrakis­(carboxyphenyl)­silane for the synthesis of porous MOFs, we paid attention to obtain new ligands based on organosilane scaffolds. Especially, we aim to synthesize pyridyl functionalized silane ligands, owing to the challenges associated with the synthesis of rigid tetrahedral ligands with this functionality.
elements.clean_text: Use of rigid tetrahedral linkers for constructing metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) is an attractive approach to synthesize novel materials that exhibit intriguing topologies and functional behavior. However, many of such MOFs suffer from the complicated ligand synthesis, limited porosity, and undesired interpenetration. Davies and Zhou et al. have prepared MOFs based on some novel silicon-centered ligands, where the introduction of the silane backbone has largely simplified the process of preparing tetrahedral ligands. Inspired by the utility of polytopic ligand such as tetrakis(carboxyphenyl)silane for the synthesis of porous MOFs, we paid attention to obtain new ligands based on organosilane scaffolds. Especially, we aim to synthesize pyridyl functionalized silane ligands, owing to the challenges associated with the synthesis of rigid tetrahedral ligands with this functionality.

elements.content: Herein, we report the synthesis of a new ligand tetrakis­(3-pyridyl)­vinylsilane (TPVS) starting from tetravinylsilane and 3-bromopyridine via the Heck Coupling reaction. Subsequent reduction of the vinylic double bonds in TPVS resulted in the formation of another ligand tetrakis­(3-pyridyl)­ethylsilane (TPES). Further, we show that these ligands are excellent building blocks for constructing framework solids by preparing two new cationic coordination networks for Cu­(II) ions. Treatment of the rigid TPVS ligand with CuCl2·2H2O gave a 3D coordination network 1 of formula [Cu4Cl3­(TPVS)4­(H2O)2]·Cl5·DMF·MeOH which contains an unusual Cu4Cl3­(H2O)2 tetranuclear cluster as the secondary building unit (SBU). Whereas, the flexible ligand TPES under similar reaction conditions formed a different 3D framework 2 of formula [Cu2Cl­(TPES)2­(H2O)2]·Cl3·2MeOH having shorter Cu2Cl­(H2O)2 linear clusters as the SBUs. Due to the presence of uncoordinated chloride ions in their pores and the electron rich ligand vinyl moieties (in the case of 1) which provide the sites of interaction, we explored the utility of these MOFs for iodine encapsulation. These studies showed a high reversible uptake of I2 for 1. Also, the presence of polynuclear Lewis acidic Cu­(II) clusters in 1 and 2 prompted us to investigate the use of these solids as catalysts. Thus, we employed both 1 and 2 for the Friedel–Crafts alkylation reaction for the efficient syntheses of bis­(indolyl)­methanes, an important class of heterocyclic compounds for their biological activity.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report the synthesis of a new ligand tetrakis(3-pyridyl)vinylsilane (TPVS) starting from tetravinylsilane and 3-bromopyridine via the Heck Coupling reaction. Subsequent reduction of the vinylic double bonds in TPVS resulted in the formation of another ligand tetrakis(3-pyridyl)ethylsilane (TPES). Further, we show that these ligands are excellent building blocks for constructing framework solids by preparing two new cationic coordination networks for Cu(II) ions. Treatment of the rigid TPVS ligand with CuCl2⋅2H2O gave a 3D coordination network 1 of formula [Cu4Cl3(TPVS)4(H2O)2]⋅Cl5⋅DMF⋅MeOH which contains an unusual Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 tetranuclear cluster as the secondary building unit (SBU). Whereas, the flexible ligand TPES under similar reaction conditions formed a different 3D framework 2 of formula [Cu2Cl(TPES)2(H2O)2]⋅Cl3⋅2MeOH having shorter Cu2Cl(H2O)2 linear clusters as the SBUs. Due to the presence of uncoordinated chloride ions in their pores and the electron rich ligand vinyl moieties (in the case of 1) which provide the sites of interaction, we explored the utility of these MOFs for iodine encapsulation. These studies showed a high reversible uptake of I2 for 1. Also, the presence of polynuclear Lewis acidic Cu(II) clusters in 1 and 2 prompted us to investigate the use of these solids as catalysts. Thus, we employed both 1 and 2 for the Friedel-Crafts alkylation reaction for the efficient syntheses of bis(indolyl)methanes, an important class of heterocyclic compounds for their biological activity.

elements.content: The rigid ligand TPVS was synthesized from the reaction of tetravinylsilane with 3-bromopyridine in the presence of Pd­[P­(tBu3)2] catalyst and triethylamine as a base, similar to the procedure we developed for the synthesis of tetrakis­(vinylpyridyl)­cyclotetrasiloxanes. The flexible ligand TPES was subsequently obtained by the reduction of vinylic bonds in TPVS by using triethylsilane as reducing agent and Pd/C as the catalyst (). The ligands were characterized by 29Si, 1H, and 13C NMR, by mass spectroscopy, and by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis in the case of TPVS ( and S1–S7, Supporting Information). The single crystals of 1 and 2 as their solvate adducts were obtained by the respective reaction of TPVS and TPES with CuCl2·2H2O in mixed dimethylformamide (DMF) and methanol solvents under solvothermal conditions at 90 °C for 36 h followed by slow evaporation of the solvents at room temperature.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

The rigid ligand TPVS was synthesized from the reaction of tetravinylsilane with 3-bromopyridine in the presence of Pd[P(tBu3)2] catalyst and triethylamine as a base, similar to the procedure we developed for the synthesis of tetrakis(vinylpyridyl)cyclotetrasiloxanes. The flexible ligand TPES was subsequently obtained by the reduction of vinylic bonds in TPVS by using triethylsilane as reducing agent and Pd/C as the catalyst (). The ligands were characterized by 29Si, 1H, and 13C NMR, by mass spectroscopy, and by single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis in the case of TPVS ( and S1-S7, Supporting Information). The single crystals of 1 and 2 as their solvate adducts were obtained by the respective reaction of TPVS and TPES with CuCl2⋅2H2O in mixed dimethylformamide (DMF) and methanol solvents under solvothermal conditions at 90 °C for 36 h followed by slow evaporation of the solvents at room temperature.

elements.clean_text: 1  Schematic Diagram for the Preparation of the Silane Ligands

elements.content: 1H and 29Si NMR spectra of TPVS and TPES ligand.
elements.clean_text: 1   1H and 29Si NMR spectra of TPVS and TPES ligand.

elements.content: The SCXRD analysis revealed that both 1 and 2 were crystallized in the tetragonal space group I4/m as their solvate adducts (Table S2 and Figures S8 and S9, Supporting Information). The structural investigations showed the formation of intricate framework structures with 3D-network topologies (). The molecular framework in 1 consists of an unusual tetranuclear Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 linear cluster as an SBU and the tetrahedral TPVS ligands as linkers. The molecular structure of 2 consists again of a cationic 3D framework buildup of the dinuclear Cu2Cl­(H2O)2 clusters as SBUs and the stacked TPES as linkers.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal structures

The SCXRD analysis revealed that both 1 and 2 were crystallized in the tetragonal space group I4/m as their solvate adducts (Table S2 and Figures S8 and S9, Supporting Information). The structural investigations showed the formation of intricate framework structures with 3D-network topologies (). The molecular framework in 1 consists of an unusual tetranuclear Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 linear cluster as an SBU and the tetrahedral TPVS ligands as linkers. The molecular structure of 2 consists again of a cationic 3D framework buildup of the dinuclear Cu2Cl(H2O)2 clusters as SBUs and the stacked TPES as linkers.

elements.content: View of the cationic 3D-networks in 1 (a) and 2 (b).
elements.clean_text: 2  View of the cationic 3D-networks in 1 (a) and 2 (b).

elements.content: Each Cu­(II) ion in 1 and 2 was attached to four different ligands. While the tetranuclear cluster in 1 is connected to 16 unique pyridyl groups (b), the dinuclear cluster in 2 is attached to eight pyridyl groups (b). In return, each TPVS and TPES ligand is four connected and is attached to Cu­(II) atoms that belong to four different linear clusters (a and a, respectively). All the Cu­(II) sites in 1 and 2 are located in an octahedral environment in which the ring N atoms of the pyridyl ligands form the square plane. In 1, the outer Cu­(II) atoms contain one terminal aqua ligand and one μ2-bridging Cl– ion at the apical positions, whereas the internal Cu­(II) atoms contain only μ2-Cl– ions at their apex (Figure S8, Supporting Information). In 2, both the Cu­(II) atoms have an octahedral N4ClO environment in which the bridging chloride ions and the terminal aqua ligands were located at the apical positions (Figure S9, Supporting Information). The void volumes of 1 and 2 were calculated by excluding the solvate molecules by using the Mercury program. The computed solvent accessible volumes in 1 and 2 were found to be 30.7% (2252.74 Å3) and 22.6% (846.16 Å3), respectively, of the total unit cell volumes.
elements.clean_text: Each Cu(II) ion in 1 and 2 was attached to four different ligands. While the tetranuclear cluster in 1 is connected to 16 unique pyridyl groups (b), the dinuclear cluster in 2 is attached to eight pyridyl groups (b). In return, each TPVS and TPES ligand is four connected and is attached to Cu(II) atoms that belong to four different linear clusters (a and a, respectively). All the Cu(II) sites in 1 and 2 are located in an octahedral environment in which the ring N atoms of the pyridyl ligands form the square plane. In 1, the outer Cu(II) atoms contain one terminal aqua ligand and one μ2-bridging Cl- ion at the apical positions, whereas the internal Cu(II) atoms contain only μ2-Cl- ions at their apex (Figure S8, Supporting Information). In 2, both the Cu(II) atoms have an octahedral N4ClO environment in which the bridging chloride ions and the terminal aqua ligands were located at the apical positions (Figure S9, Supporting Information). The void volumes of 1 and 2 were calculated by excluding the solvate molecules by using the Mercury program. The computed solvent accessible volumes in 1 and 2 were found to be 30.7% (2252.74 Å3) and 22.6% (846.16 Å3), respectively, of the total unit cell volumes.

elements.content: Topological representation of 1 showing (a) the arrangement of the Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 clusters around TPVS ligand; (b) the arrangement of the TPVS ligands around the Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 cluster (hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity); (c) the underlying trinodal 4,5,6-c net (4,5,6T115) in 1; and (d) its similarity with tcs topology via the connection of the second μ2-chloride bridges represented by green and yellow spheres that can superimpose onto each other to form the double-layered aggregates.
elements.clean_text: 3  Topological representation of 1 showing (a) the arrangement of the Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 clusters around TPVS ligand; (b) the arrangement of the TPVS ligands around the Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 cluster (hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity); (c) the underlying trinodal 4,5,6-c net (4,5,6T115) in 1; and (d) its similarity with tcs topology via the connection of the second μ2-chloride bridges represented by green and yellow spheres that can superimpose onto each other to form the double-layered aggregates.

elements.content: Topological representation of 2 showing (a) the arrangement of the Cu2Cl­(H2O)2 clusters around TPES ligand and (b) TPES ligands around the Cu2Cl­(H2O)2 cluster (hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity); (c) the underlying binodal 4,5-c net of tcs topology and (d) the view of its single layer with sql topology. Green and yellow spheres represent the μ2-chloride ligands that superimpose onto each other to form the tcs network.
elements.clean_text: 4  Topological representation of 2 showing (a) the arrangement of the Cu2Cl(H2O)2 clusters around TPES ligand and (b) TPES ligands around the Cu2Cl(H2O)2 cluster (hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity); (c) the underlying binodal 4,5-c net of tcs topology and (d) the view of its single layer with sql topology. Green and yellow spheres represent the μ2-chloride ligands that superimpose onto each other to form the tcs network.

elements.content: The topological description of the crystal structures was carried out in the ToposPro program using several simplification procedures in which the metal atoms remain intact, but ligands are represented by their center of mass, keeping the connectivity of the ligand with its neighbors. The standard simplification procedure resulted in a 4,5,6-coordinated trinodal net (4,5,6-c) with a new topology in 1 represented by the symbol 4,5,6T115 (c) and a 4,5-coordinated (4,5-c) tcs net in 2 (c). The ligands are always 4-connected, and the copper atoms are 5 and 6-coordinated nodes in these nets. It is interesting to compare the structural topologies present in 1 and 2. The tcs topology in 2 (c) is formed by the stacking of two sql layers (simple square-layers) onto each other. These layers are connected by the μ2-chloride ligands (green and yellow spheres) in such a way that green squares are superimposed on the yellow ones (d). In 1, the number of sql layers are doubled (d) and further connected by another μ2-chloride ligand, leading to a hitherto unknown topology for the trinodal 4,5,6-c network (c). Nevertheless, the standard structural representation is unable to unveil the clear interrelation between the two MOFs fully. A more meaningful representation can be obtained by considering the whole linear clusters as a single node or building blocks and the four connected ligands (TPVS and TPES) as another node. This arrangement results in the connection of Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 clusters with 16 TPVS ligands and Cu2Cl­(H2O)2 clusters coordinated with eight TPES ligands in the structures of 1 and 2, respectively. This representation leads to a new highly coordinated binodal 4,16-c net in 1 represented by the symbol 4,16T9 and to the well-known 4,8-c binodal net of the flu topological type in 2 (Figure S10, Supporting Information). A detailed search through the CSD for linear and finite copper–halogen chains using the ToposPro revealed that the structure of 1 is the only one that contains such a long linear Cu4Cl3 copper cluster as building units that are joined by ligands into the 3D framework. There is one instance of the resemblance of 2 for the OQIRAI structure with a rod-type Cu2I3 cluster (Table S4, Supporting Information). Other 3D frameworks comprise square Cu4Cl cores with μ4-chloride ions.

The standard simplification procedure resulted in a 4,5,6-coordinated trinodal net (4,5,6-c) with a new topology in 1 represented by the symbol 4,5,6T115 (c) and a 4,5-coordinated (4,5-c) tcs net in 2 (c). The ligands are always 4-connected, and the copper atoms are 5 and 6-coordinated nodes in these nets. It is interesting to compare the structural topologies present in 1 and 2. The tcs topology in 2 (c) is formed by the stacking of two sql layers (simple square-layers) onto each other. These layers are connected by the μ2-chloride ligands (green and yellow spheres) in such a way that green squares are superimposed on the yellow ones (d). In 1, the number of sql layers are doubled (d) and further connected by another μ2-chloride ligand, leading to a hitherto unknown topology for the trinodal 4,5,6-c network (c). Nevertheless, the standard structural representation is unable to unveil the clear interrelation between the two MOFs fully. A more meaningful representation can be obtained by considering the whole linear clusters as a single node or building blocks and the four connected ligands (TPVS and TPES) as another node. This arrangement results in the connection of Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 clusters with 16 TPVS ligands and Cu2Cl(H2O)2 clusters coordinated with eight TPES ligands in the structures of 1 and 2, respectively. This representation leads to a new highly coordinated binodal 4,16-c net in 1 represented by the symbol 4,16T9 and to the well-known 4,8-c binodal net of the flu topological type in 2 (Figure S10, Supporting Information). A detailed search through the CSD for linear and finite copper-halogen chains using the ToposPro revealed that the structure of 1 is the only one that contains such a long linear Cu4Cl3 copper cluster as building units that are joined by ligands into the 3D framework. There is one instance of the resemblance of 2 for the OQIRAI structure with a rod-type Cu2I3 cluster (Table S4, Supporting Information). Other 3D frameworks comprise square Cu4Cl cores with μ4-chloride ions.

elements.content: The guest free samples of 1 and 2 were obtained by evacuating the solvents present in their pores. Before evacuation, the high boiling DMF solvate in 1 was exchanged with MeOH by soaking the crystals in methanol. From the PXRD analysis, it is apparent that 1 retains its crystallinity and framework integrity even after removal of the pore solvents. However, compound 2 was found to lose its crystallinity after removal of its methanol solvates (Figures S11 and S12, Supporting Information). Further, TGA analysis of 1, 1′ (MeOH exchanged), and 1″ (evacuated) showed that the solvent exchange route could achieve full evacuation. The variable temperature PXRD and TGA analyses show that the framework is stable up to 250 °C. The PXRD data obtained on the samples of 1 show that all the prominent diffraction peaks in 1′ and 1″ can be matched with those present in as made 1 (Figures S13 and S14, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Iodine uptake studies of 1 

The guest free samples of 1 and 2 were obtained by evacuating the solvents present in their pores. Before evacuation, the high boiling DMF solvate in 1 was exchanged with MeOH by soaking the crystals in methanol. From the PXRD analysis, it is apparent that 1 retains its crystallinity and framework integrity even after removal of the pore solvents. However, compound 2 was found to lose its crystallinity after removal of its methanol solvates (Figures S11 and S12, Supporting Information). Further, TGA analysis of 1, 1' (MeOH exchanged), and 1" (evacuated) showed that the solvent exchange route could achieve full evacuation. The variable temperature PXRD and TGA analyses show that the framework is stable up to 250 °C. The PXRD data obtained on the samples of 1 show that all the prominent diffraction peaks in 1' and 1" can be matched with those present in as made 1 (Figures S13 and S14, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Owing to the presence of vinylic double bonds and polar Cl– ions, we checked the gas adsorption and I2 uptake behavior of 1 (Figure S15, Supporting Information). Thus, when 1″ was exposed to iodine vapor in a screw-capped vial at 70 °C, the color of the sample changed progressively from green to brown within 1 h. A saturated iodine loading of about 45.2% was reached within 10 h to generate the I2 loaded MOF 1 (I2⊂1). The TGA plot of I2⊂1 gave an I2 content of around 48.5%, indicated by a sharp weight loss at 100 °C (a and b). Further, the iodine uptake of 1 was investigated in solution by soaking 1″ (50 mg) in the 0.03 M ethanol (3 mL) solution of I2. The apparent uptake of I2 was confirmed by the fading of the dark brown color of the I2 solution to pale red with a concomitant increase in the intensity of color for the powdered sample of 1 (Figure S16a, Supporting Information). Notably, the I2 uptake of 1 was found to be reversible both in solution and in the solid-state. When a solid sample of I2⊂1 was heated at 100 °C for 10 h, 87% of the encapsulated iodine was completely removed, and 1″ was regenerated upon subsequent evacuation under vacuum. From the TGA and PXRD analysis, the retention of crystallinity and structural integrity of 1 during the reversible I2 loading and unloading processes can be confirmed (c and S17, Supporting Information). Similarly, the I2 desorption in solution can be observed when the sample of I2⊂1 is immersed in neat ethanol. Monitoring the I2 release profile by UV–visible spectroscopy indicates that the onset of I2 release takes place as soon as I2⊂1 comes into contact with ethanol. A gradual increase in the release profile can be observed as the time progresses and intensity of the I2 absorption saturates in 2 h (d and S16b, Supporting Information).

elements.content: (a) Gravimetric uptake of I2 by 1 and (b) the I2 release profile of I2⊂1 in the solid-state. Insets show changes in sample color before and after I2 uptake. (c) TGA profiles showing a reversible I2 uptake by 1″. (d) UV–visible spectral evolution showing the release of iodine from I2⊂1 in ethanol.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Gravimetric uptake of I2 by 1 and (b) the I2 release profile of I2⊂1 in the solid-state. Insets show changes in sample color before and after I2 uptake. (c) TGA profiles showing a reversible I2 uptake by 1". (d) UV-visible spectral evolution showing the release of iodine from I2⊂1 in ethanol.

elements.content: To understand the role of uncoordinated chloride ions for the uptake of I2 in 1, we exchanged the Cl– ions with other ones such as nitrate, bromide, and iodide ions. The well ground crystalline powders of 1 were separately suspended in the 1 M aqueous solution of NaNO3, KBr, and NaI for the exchange studies. After 3 days, the exchanged samples were washed with distilled water several times and then dried under vacuum. The exchange products were analyzed by IR, PXRD, and TGA methods which showed these compounds exhibit excellent stability in water. The PXRD of the exchanged samples shows similar patterns to that of 1 indicating that the basic framework remains unchanged upon anion exchange (a). In the IR spectra of the nitrate exchanged sample a new peak at 1311 cm–1 appeared due to the N–O symmetric stretching vibrations of the nitrate ion (Figure S18, Supporting Information). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDX) were performed to investigate the surface state of the samples. The SEM images showed that the morphology of 1 remains unaffected in all the anion-exchanged samples (Figure S19, Supporting Information). The EDX results reveal that the relative atomic ratios of Cu, Si, and C on the surface of all the anion-exchanged samples are mostly identical to that of 1. These results indicate that no surface decomposition has occurred during the exchange process. Furthermore, the quantitative presence of Br– and I– ions was identified from the EDX profiles (Figure S20–S23, Supporting Information). In the nitrate exchanged sample, the atomic ratio of Cl– ion decreased considerably with a concomitant increase in the oxygen ratio. These observations were supported by the SEM-element mappings which gave a clear evidence for the exchange of anions in all these cases (Figures S24–S27, Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: To understand the role of uncoordinated chloride ions for the uptake of I2 in 1, we exchanged the Cl- ions with other ones such as nitrate, bromide, and iodide ions. The well ground crystalline powders of 1 were separately suspended in the 1 M aqueous solution of NaNO3, KBr, and NaI for the exchange studies. After 3 days, the exchanged samples were washed with distilled water several times and then dried under vacuum. The exchange products were analyzed by IR, PXRD, and TGA methods which showed these compounds exhibit excellent stability in water. The PXRD of the exchanged samples shows similar patterns to that of 1 indicating that the basic framework remains unchanged upon anion exchange (a). In the IR spectra of the nitrate exchanged sample a new peak at 1311 cm-1 appeared due to the N-O symmetric stretching vibrations of the nitrate ion (Figure S18, Supporting Information). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDX) were performed to investigate the surface state of the samples. The SEM images showed that the morphology of 1 remains unaffected in all the anion-exchanged samples (Figure S19, Supporting Information). The EDX results reveal that the relative atomic ratios of Cu, Si, and C on the surface of all the anion-exchanged samples are mostly identical to that of 1. These results indicate that no surface decomposition has occurred during the exchange process. Furthermore, the quantitative presence of Br- and I- ions was identified from the EDX profiles (Figure S20-S23, Supporting Information). In the nitrate exchanged sample, the atomic ratio of Cl- ion decreased considerably with a concomitant increase in the oxygen ratio. These observations were supported by the SEM-element mappings which gave a clear evidence for the exchange of anions in all these cases (Figures S24-S27, Supporting Information).

elements.content: Comparisons of anion-exchanged samples of 1 (a) PXRD patterns and (b) gravimetric uptake of I2.
elements.clean_text: 6  Comparisons of anion-exchanged samples of 1 (a) PXRD patterns and (b) gravimetric uptake of I2.

elements.content: To explore their anion-dependent I2 adsorption properties, these exchanged compounds were exposed to iodine vapors in a closed vial at 70 °C for 12 h. The TGA plot of the NO3 – exchanged sample showed a considerable decrease of I2 uptake from 48.5 to 24.0%, while the Br– and I– exchanged compounds showed a marginally lower uptake of 37.7 and 32.0%, respectively. These observations were consistent with their corresponding gravimetric uptake profiles (b and S28–S31, Supporting Information). These observations suggest that the presence of halide counterions has a clear influence on the iodine uptake characteristics of 1 which are found to interact better with I2 in comparison with nitrate ion. The better I2 uptake of 1 in the presence of Cl– ions over the other two halides can be attributed to its smaller size, resulting in a larger surface area for adsorption. Known examples of MOFs with high I2 affinity utilize organic ligands featuring π-conjugated backbone and electron-pair donor (both neutral and anionic) groups such as pyridyl, alcohol, ether, and amine functionalities. All these functional groups can interact with I2 via stable charge-transfer complexation or halogen bond formation and thereby facilitate the increased adsorption of I2. Furthermore, the reversible capture of I2 by 1 has implications for addressing some important societal problems such as the trapping radioactive isotope of 129I from nuclear waste and release of the clinically useful 131I isotope for cancer therapy.
elements.clean_text: To explore their anion-dependent I2 adsorption properties, these exchanged compounds were exposed to iodine vapors in a closed vial at 70 °C for 12 h. The TGA plot of the NO3 - exchanged sample showed a considerable decrease of I2 uptake from 48.5 to 24.0%, while the Br- and I- exchanged compounds showed a marginally lower uptake of 37.7 and 32.0%, respectively. These observations were consistent with their corresponding gravimetric uptake profiles (b and S28-S31, Supporting Information). These observations suggest that the presence of halide counterions has a clear influence on the iodine uptake characteristics of 1 which are found to interact better with I2 in comparison with nitrate ion. The better I2 uptake of 1 in the presence of Cl- ions over the other two halides can be attributed to its smaller size, resulting in a larger surface area for adsorption. Known examples of MOFs with high I2 affinity utilize organic ligands featuring π-conjugated backbone and electron-pair donor (both neutral and anionic) groups such as pyridyl, alcohol, ether, and amine functionalities. All these functional groups can interact with I2 via stable charge-transfer complexation or halogen bond formation and thereby facilitate the increased adsorption of I2. Furthermore, the reversible capture of I2 by 1 has implications for addressing some important societal problems such as the trapping radioactive isotope of 129I from nuclear waste and release of the clinically useful 131I isotope for cancer therapy.

elements.content: Finally, compounds 1 and 2 were employed for the Cu­(II) catalyzed synthesis of bis­(indolyl)­methanes by indole Friedel–Crafts alkylation under solvent-free conditions. Thus, the treatment of substituted benzaldehydes with indole in a 1:2 ratio in the presence of the catalysts (5 wt % of 1″ or 2) at room-temperature afforded the corresponding bis­(indolyl)­methanes in quantitative yields of 75–90% in the case of 1″ and 50–80% in the case of 2 in the isolated form ( and Table S1, Supporting Information). Remarkably, compounds 1″ and 2 can be reused five times without any significant loss in their catalytic activity (Table S5, Supporting Information). The comparison of the PXRD patterns before and after the second and fifth catalytic cycle (recovered after removing the organic compounds in DCM) demonstrated that the crystallinity of the MOFs (1″ and 2) is retained during these catalytic reactions. Also, it is observed that the catalysts are stable after the second catalytic cycle, but they start to degrade slowly after the fifth cycle (Figures S32 and S33, Supporting Information). Furthermore, to determine whether the surface or the inner pores of the MOF act as the site of the catalytic activity, we studied the size-dependent catalytic activity of 1″. For that, the powdered solid of 1″ was centrifuged (at 7540 rpm) in methanol for 7 min, and the smaller particles of size less than 300 μm were recovered from the supernatant part and dried. The catalytic studies revealed the smaller particles show a sizable decrease in the catalytic activity (20% yield) in comparison with that of the larger ones (74% yield) for the p-nitrobenzaldehyde substrate. This indicates that the catalytic reaction takes place on the surface of these MOFs via the displacement of the weakly bound axial aqua ligands at the Cu­(II) sites. Although the catalytic efficiency of 1″ is expected to increase upon removal of the axial aqua ligands, such studies were not performed due to the loss of crystallinity (Figure S11, Supporting Information) during the high-temperature activation process.
elements.clean_text:
Catalytic activities of 1 and 2 

Finally, compounds 1 and 2 were employed for the Cu(II) catalyzed synthesis of bis(indolyl)methanes by indole Friedel-Crafts alkylation under solvent-free conditions. Thus, the treatment of substituted benzaldehydes with indole in a 1:2 ratio in the presence of the catalysts (5 wt % of 1" or 2) at room-temperature afforded the corresponding bis(indolyl)methanes in quantitative yields of 75-90% in the case of 1" and 50-80% in the case of 2 in the isolated form ( and Table S1, Supporting Information). Remarkably, compounds 1" and 2 can be reused five times without any significant loss in their catalytic activity (Table S5, Supporting Information). The comparison of the PXRD patterns before and after the second and fifth catalytic cycle (recovered after removing the organic compounds in DCM) demonstrated that the crystallinity of the MOFs (1" and 2) is retained during these catalytic reactions. Also, it is observed that the catalysts are stable after the second catalytic cycle, but they start to degrade slowly after the fifth cycle (Figures S32 and S33, Supporting Information). Furthermore, to determine whether the surface or the inner pores of the MOF act as the site of the catalytic activity, we studied the size-dependent catalytic activity of 1". For that, the powdered solid of 1" was centrifuged (at 7540 rpm) in methanol for 7 min, and the smaller particles of size less than 300 μm were recovered from the supernatant part and dried. The catalytic studies revealed the smaller particles show a sizable decrease in the catalytic activity (20% yield) in comparison with that of the larger ones (74% yield) for the p-nitrobenzaldehyde substrate. This indicates that the catalytic reaction takes place on the surface of these MOFs via the displacement of the weakly bound axial aqua ligands at the Cu(II) sites. Although the catalytic efficiency of 1" is expected to increase upon removal of the axial aqua ligands, such studies were not performed due to the loss of crystallinity (Figure S11, Supporting Information) during the high-temperature activation process.

elements.content: Solvent free Friedel–Crafts alkylation of indole with benzaldehydes by 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: 7  Solvent free Friedel-Crafts alkylation of indole with benzaldehydes by 1 and 2.

elements.content: To our knowledge, only two examples related to the heterogeneous catalytic indole Friedel–Crafts alkylation tandem reactions have so far been reported. These reported reactions were catalyzed by porous aluminosilicate materials and by triphenylphosphine-m-sulfonate salts to generate the corresponding Friedel–Crafts alkylation products in 91 and 75% yields, respectively. However, these reactions require high temperatures and involve toxic species such as CBr4 as additives. Compounds 1 and 2 have other advantages, as they can catalyze these reactions at room temperature and importantly could offer a considerably clean synthetic approach as they require no additional organic solvents for this reaction.
elements.clean_text: To our knowledge, only two examples related to the heterogeneous catalytic indole Friedel-Crafts alkylation tandem reactions have so far been reported. These reported reactions were catalyzed by porous aluminosilicate materials and by triphenylphosphine-m-sulfonate salts to generate the corresponding Friedel-Crafts alkylation products in 91 and 75% yields, respectively. However, these reactions require high temperatures and involve toxic species such as CBr4 as additives. Compounds 1 and 2 have other advantages, as they can catalyze these reactions at room temperature and importantly could offer a considerably clean synthetic approach as they require no additional organic solvents for this reaction.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have reported a simple synthetic protocol for preparing two tetrahedral tetrapyridyl ligands utilizing an organosilane scaffold. These ligands feature rigid vinyl and flexible ethyl spacers in their backbone. The ligands were employed in reaction with CuCl2 to obtain two novel 3D coordination networks having unique linear Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 and Cu2Cl­(H2O)2 clusters as secondary building units. A search of the CSD shows that the Cu4Cl3 motif of 1 is the longest building unit among copper halide clusters leading to the formation of a 4,5,6-c connected net with a new topology 4,5,6T115. The complex 1 (in the activated state) shows very good uptake and release of I2 adsorption capacity in both vapor and solution phases. The I2 adsorption studies of the anion-exchanged samples of 1 show better uptake characteristics for the sample containing Cl– ions due to its better interaction and the availability of larger surface area. Furthermore, these frameworks were found to be good catalysts for Friedel–Crafts alkylation reactions. The size-dependent catalytic activity of 1 shows a better activity for larger-sized particles which indicates that the catalytically active sites are located on the surface of the MOF. The present work shows that organosilane backbones offer an excellent platform for obtaining framework materials in 3D-topologies. This strategy can be further utilized in the future for obtaining MOFs with unique structures and functionalities.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we have reported a simple synthetic protocol for preparing two tetrahedral tetrapyridyl ligands utilizing an organosilane scaffold. These ligands feature rigid vinyl and flexible ethyl spacers in their backbone. The ligands were employed in reaction with CuCl2 to obtain two novel 3D coordination networks having unique linear Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 and Cu2Cl(H2O)2 clusters as secondary building units. A search of the CSD shows that the Cu4Cl3 motif of 1 is the longest building unit among copper halide clusters leading to the formation of a 4,5,6-c connected net with a new topology 4,5,6T115. The complex 1 (in the activated state) shows very good uptake and release of I2 adsorption capacity in both vapor and solution phases. The I2 adsorption studies of the anion-exchanged samples of 1 show better uptake characteristics for the sample containing Cl- ions due to its better interaction and the availability of larger surface area. Furthermore, these frameworks were found to be good catalysts for Friedel-Crafts alkylation reactions. The size-dependent catalytic activity of 1 shows a better activity for larger-sized particles which indicates that the catalytically active sites are located on the surface of the MOF. The present work shows that organosilane backbones offer an excellent platform for obtaining framework materials in 3D-topologies. This strategy can be further utilized in the future for obtaining MOFs with unique structures and functionalities.

cln_elements.content: Topological representation of 1 showing (a) the arrangement of the Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 clusters around TPVS ligand; (b) the arrangement of the TPVS ligands around the Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 cluster (hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity); (c) the underlying trinodal 4,5,6-c net (4,5,6T115) in 1; and (d) its similarity with tcs topology via the connection of the second μ2-chloride bridges represented by green and yellow spheres that can superimpose onto each other to form the double-layered aggregates.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Topological representation of 1 showing (a) the arrangement of the Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 clusters around TPVS ligand; (b) the arrangement of the TPVS ligands around the Cu4Cl3(H2O)2 cluster (hydrogen atoms omitted for clarity); (c) the underlying trinodal 4,5,6-c net (4,5,6T115) in 1; and (d) its similarity with tcs topology via the connection of the second μ2-chloride bridges represented by green and yellow spheres that can superimpose onto each other to form the double-layered aggregates.

Green and yellow spheres represent the μ2-chloride ligands that superimpose onto each other to form the tcs network.

metadata.title:
A 3D Coordination Network Built from CuII
4Cl3(H2O)2 Linear Clusters
and Tetrapyridyl Tetrahedral Silane Ligands: Reversible Iodine Uptake
and Friedel–Crafts Alkylation Reactions
